newsitem.title: USA: Russia still seeks lower yields - finance minister.
newsitem.headline: Russia still seeks lower yields - finance minister.

text.p: Russia will stick to its plans to cut interest rates, despite last week's spike in yields on its Treasury bills, Russian Finance Minister Alexander Livshits said on Monday.
"We will not change our policy, the policy of lowering yields," he told reporters outside a meeting of the International Monetary Fund's development committee.
Livshits said this was the only way to lower interest rates. "Next year we are aiming for rates of 25-30 percent," he said.
At an auction of six-month GKO discount T-bills last week, yields spiked upwards to about 80 percent from the mid-60s.
Yields were steady on a three-month issue and dealers said a bank with close ties to the government had bought much of the issue.
Dealers said the government had paid the high yields on the six-month issue, in part to pay striking workers.
Russia eased access to its government securities market for non-residents in August in an effort to reduce yields.
The IMF would like the market to be further liberalised. The high yields are seen as crowding out investment.
But Russian officials, wary of what happened in Mexico, say they need some restrictions to be able to control the flow of funds.
